Obviously, this is extremely problematic. Let us imagine, for instance, that the Russians did not carry out a hack-and-leak operation against the DNC, but blackmailed the US President into resigning or directly tampered with the election results. Alternatively, let us imagine that ‘State A’ and ‘State B’ are both competing to sell jet-fighters to ‘State C’. State A decides to infect the electronic systems of the jet-fighters manufactured by State B, in order to cause failures, damage their reputation, end their production and —at the end of the day—win the bid and eliminate a competitor. If these areas are not within the domaine réservé anymore, then even those extreme forms of meddling in the political or economic affairs of another state would not qualify as prohibited interventions.
Another problem with the concept of domaine réservé is that it fails to regulate those cyber operations exclusively directed against private actors, even if they are vital to the social[33] and cultural system of a state.[34] For instance, the cyberattacks against Sony Pictures Entertainment (SPE) in 2014 revealed the attempts of foreign governments to meddle with values that are essential to liberal democracies, such as freedom of expression. As a matter of fact, 'the real motive of the operation appears to have been an attempt to prevent the film's global distribution as well as an attempt to deter SPE and other studios from insulting the North Korean regime'.[35] It must be said that this attempt was partially successful, as SPE had to cancel the film's release.[36] This decision was criticised by President Obama himself, who declared:
[w]e cannot have a society where some dictator someplace can start imposing censorship here in the United States ... Imagine if producers and distributors and others start engaging in self-censorship because they don't want to offend the sensibilities of someone who's sensibilities probably need to be offended.[37]
Yet, and by virtue of the lex lata, the fact that such attacks were exclusively targeting a private company excludes the possibility to describe them in terms of prohibited interventions.[38] And indeed, the US government opted for an

alternative term: ‘an act of cyber-vandalism’. Let us imagine that the goal of North Korea was to prompt the adoption of a new law in the USA, which would increase movie censorship. Alternatively, let us imagine that the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK) launches a series of attacks against the movie industry in France, to protest the upcoming release of a similar comedy depicting the North Korean regime. They paralyse the movie industry, and studios experience significant economic losses. The goal is to put such pressure on the Minister of Culture that he is forced to refuse to grant the movie a ‘visa d’exploitation’ (ie the authorisation to broadcast a film). If one admits that restrictions to the freedom of expression are still part of the domaine réservé—which is arguably not the case, as human rights conventions usually regulate this area—these attacks are more likely to qualify as interventions because the private actor was only targeted to obtain something from the state. In fact, attacks against the movie industry or newspapers are on the rise, and the resort to ‘criminal hackers’ might just ‘provide a cheap and easy way of censoring the press’. To alleviate this risk, I suggest replacement of the old-fashioned concept of domaine réservé with the newer domaine privilégié.
## B. The concept of domaine privilégié
The objections raised against the concept of domaine réservé are the following: it has been stripped of most of its content and it is maladjusted to the new contribution of non-state actors to the exercise of fundamental freedoms. Consequently, a domaine réservé—based principle of non-interventions fails to protect the free choice and the stability of a political, economic, social or cultural system from foreign attacks. This is where the domaine privilégié comes in, as it appears necessary to opt for a concept with clear-cut contours, which remains unaffected by the development of international law, and protects the fundamental interests of a state and its population. Ago took pains, though, to distinguish necessity from the naturalist doctrine of the ‘Fundamental Rights of States’. The early roots of this doctrine can be found in Hobbes’s writings, and it was theorised by authors such as Wolff and Vattel. Wolff considered that nations had a ‘duty of self-preservation’. Hence, ‘every nation ha[d] the right to those means by which it can, as far as possible, avert the peril of destruction and avoid those things which can bring destruction upon it’. Vattel defined certain ‘inalienable rights’ of nations, those required by ‘necessity’ or for its ‘preservation’—and their satisfaction usually justified the use of force. Years later, Gidel thought that states had ‘fundamental’ or ‘inherent’ rights, which were ‘absolute, inviolable and unalienable’, and included ‘preservation, independence, equality, respect, international trade’. Self-preservation actually gained a negative reputation, as it was often ‘the criterion used to justify the rights of states to have recourse to arms’ and ‘for the violation of the rights of other subjects’. Yet, literature of the post-war era reveals an alternative reading of self-preservation, which is more respectful of the rights of other states. For instance, Alfaro highlighted that ‘[s]elf-preservation rests upon the reciprocal

Hence, I argue that non-intervention, too, should protect the fundamental interests of a state, rather than being limited to the domaine réservé. Yet, in contrast with necessity or the early doctrine of self-preservation, it does not provide justification for breaching the rights of other states, but results in a duty of abstention: states must refrain from meddling with the domaine privilégié of other states. This domaine privilégié includes not only the elements necessary for the very survival of a state but also those that are essential for its independence, autonomy and stability.
First, it protects the political organisation of the state, including the forms of government, the rule of law, personal, collective and political freedoms, as well as the electoral process in full (primary, local and general elections, referenda, etc). Under this new framework, the hack-and-leak operation that targeted the DNC would meddle with the American electoral process and, therefore, with the US domaine privilégié. It would also be affected in the event of cyber operations directed at the movie industry or press organs—like the SPE scenarios—as they seek to restrict the exercise of fundamental freedoms.
Secondly, it encompasses internal and external security. For instance, the 2015 data breach at the US Office of Personnel Management (OPM) compromised the security of the USA, as it could 'reveal the identities of CIA [Central Intelligence Agency] operatives serving under diplomatic cover'.69 In this case, the domaine privilégié of the USA was obviously affected.
Thirdly, it incorporates major economic interests, ie 'interests so essential that a breach of them threatens the economic ... stability' of the state.70 Key and energy industries, major employers, transports, banking transactions and telecommunications may qualify as such. For instance, and considering that the petrochemical sector 'is a core part of the Saudi economy',71 the cyberattacks against oil companies in Saudi Arabia may affect its domaine privilégié. The same would be true for the 2017 NotPetya attacks, which were aimed at disrupting Ukraine's financial system.72 Insofar as they may provoke the downfall

of the aviation industry in 'State B', the cyberattacks induced by 'State A' in the fictitious example above would also impair the former's domaine privilégié.
Fourthly, it embraces public services, including health and social systems. Hence, state-sponsored attacks against hospitals would obviously affect the domaine privilégié. For instance, in March 2020, the Brno University Hospital had to turn away patients 'suffering serious conditions', and 'urgent surgeries' were postponed following a cyberattack, which shutdown all computers.73 In such situations, the impact on the domaine privilégié is obvious.
Fifthly, the domaine privilégié may extend to the preservation of a state's environment. For example, the 2017 NotPetya attacks also broke the monitoring systems of the nuclear power plant in Chernobyl, and they could have led to long-lasting damage to Ukraine's environment.74
Foreign meddling with this domaine privilégié would be prohibited, unless adopted within the legal framework of countermeasures.75 If the proposed concept of domaine privilégié is clearly de lege ferenda,76 it results from state practice that some governments might actually be sympathetic, for example, to the protection of main economic interests through the principle of non-intervention.77

# 4. A reconceptualisation of coercion
In this section, I will first explain the traditional definition of the concept of coercion, and why it is unsatisfactory in the digital era (Subsection 4A). I then put forward my own reappraisal of the concept of coercion (Subsection 4B).
## A. The traditional definition of coercion
Coercion must be equated with the implementation of ‘coercive measures’ or ‘coercive methods’ and must be distinguished from the mere influence or persuasion. In fact, Vattel described interference as an ‘attempt to put a constraint on [the] deliberations’ of another state, whereas Kant put down that ‘[n]o State shall by force interfere with the constitution or government of another State’. The Montevideo Convention on the Rights and Duties of States of 1933 established a duty of non-recognition of situations ‘obtained by force whether this consist[ed] in the employment of arms, in threatening diplomatic representations, or in any other effective coercive measures’. The Charter of the Organization of American States (OAS) prevented states from ‘us[ing] or encouraging[ing] the use of coercive measures of an economic or political character in order to force the sovereign will of another state and obtain from it advantages of any kind’. It also underlined that ‘[n]o territorial acquisitions or special advantages obtained either by force or by other means of coercion shall be recognized’. In the Nicaragua case, the ICJ used the term ‘methods of coercion’. Another question that arises is whether intention is necessary. An analysis of the ICJ case law confirms that intention must be taken into account.

This understanding of coercion sets a high threshold and most cyber operations do not pass this test. If a state was demanding another one to declare the wrong candidate a winner of the elections, or to declare the favourite candidate ineligible on false grounds, under the threat of launching a debilitating wave of cyberattacks, then the criterion of coercion would be met. ## B. The reappraisal of coercion
As mentioned above, ‘coercion’ historically occurs ‘when a State deploys those means of pressure against another State, that are of a sufficiently serious nature to, and with the intention to, compel the latter to act in a certain way – or to refrain from acting in a certain way – and against its own will’. Yet, this definition is unsatisfactory in the cyber realm and fails to grasp new types of highly disruptive cyberattacks. Any reappraisal of the coercion is a risky exercise, though, and we must beware of excessively watering down this concept, at the risk of hindering basic interstate relations.
In particular, the distinction between plain ‘influence’ and constraint must be maintained. It is likely that states will use the information they obtained through cyberespionage operations to influence the negotiation strategies and decision-making of other states, in line with their own interests. It is also likely that states that suffered cyberattacks or acts of cyberespionage will adapt their internal and external policies, either for the purpose of repairing the damage or for preventing further strikes. It is finally appropriate to touch on the issue of economic cyberespionage. Under the framework put forward in this article, it is clear that only the most severe forms of intellectual property theft (if there are any) would qualify as prohibited interventions—those prone to threatening the economic stability of a state. If this phenomenon is indeed problematic and calls—in my opinion—for legal answers, tailor-made rules are required. In that sense, the Paris Call is interesting, as signatories pledged to '[p]revent ICT-enabled theft of intellectual property, including trade secrets or other confidential business information, with the intent of providing competitive advantages to companies or commercial sector'.
# 5. Conclusion
In this article, I championed the applicability of non-intervention in cyberspace. In my view, such applicability is welcomed by the international community and does not raise theoretical questions about the nature of sovereignty or the militarisation of cyberspace. However, I expressed fears that this principle becomes obsolete if we keep equating 'matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely' with the notion of domaine réservé. I thus recommended that, for the purpose of non-intervention, we ought to adopt the notion of state domaine privilégié. The latter encompasses the political organisation of a state, its internal and external security, major economic interests and public services (including the health and social systems), as well as the preservation of a state's environment. # Reviving the Principle of Non-Intervention in Cyberspace: The Path Forward
Thibault Moulin*
## Abstract
The applicability of existing rules of international law (namely sovereignty or the prohibition to use force) is currently challenged in cyberspace. In contrast, the relevance of the non-intervention principle is accepted by states and raises less questions about the ‘territoriality’ or the ‘militarization’ of cyberspace. At first sight, it thus appears as a convenient source for the regulation of cyberthreats. However, the *Nicaragua* case also established a stringent test for a foreign interference to qualify as an unlawful intervention. First, it must bear ‘on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty to decide freely’ (ie the ‘domaine réservé’). Then, it must involve ‘methods of coercion in regard to such choices’. I contend that both criteria are maladjusted to address cyberthreats and must be reconceptualised. In fact, the *domaine réservé* describes domains where states are free from international rules. However, few domains, including electoral processes or main economic orientations, are totally isolated from international law. I thus argue that it must be reconceptualised into the so-called ‘domaine privilégié’. It consists of a domain with clear-cut contours, unaffected by the developments of international law, which encompasses the fundamental interests of a state and its population. Then, coercion describes situations where a state is compelled to act, or to refrain from acting, in a certain fashion. This traditional approach is also problematic, and I argue that coercion must be understood in terms of deprivation of control.
## 1. Introduction
In his separate opinion attached to the *Nicaragua* case, ICJ President Nagendra Singh felt that he could not ‘conclude this opinion without emphasizing the key

In fact, he considered that '[t]o ignore this doctrine is to undermine international order and to promote violence and bloodshed which may prove catastrophic in the end'. More than three decades later, international lawyers' attempts at regulating emerging technologies reveal that the 'principle' of non-intervention might be relevant in situations where there is no risk of 'bloodshed', in a world that lacks flesh and bones: cyberspace. Against this background, this article is structured as follows. In the next section, I explain that the principle of non-intervention is clearly applicable in cyberspace. I underline, in particular, that its application to cyberthreats is less controversial than other rules, namely sovereignty or the prohibition to use force—whose implementation in a 'digital' space instead of a 'physical' space remains disputed (Section 2). In the third section, I analyse what is domaine réservé and the reason why this concept is no longer adequate to address cyber activities. In particular, I raise doubts about the current integration of political processes and economic orientations within the domaine réservé, and I contend that it fails to protect those private actors that are vital to the social and cultural system of a state (such as press bodies). I then explain why the notion of domaine réservé should be replaced by the notion of domaine privilégié, what it means and how it would apply to cyberspace (Section 3). In the fourth section, I dwell on the concept of coercion and explain what it means. I underline that the traditional understanding of coercion fails to grasp situations where the state is deprived of its control, and I support a balanced reinterpretation of this concept (Section 4). Some conclusions are offered in the last section (Section 5).

# 3. A reconceptualisation of the domaine réservé
In this section, I will first explain the concept of domaine réservé, and why this old-fashioned concept is unsatisfactory in the digital era (Subsection 3A). To alleviate this problem, I argue in favour of a reconceptualisation of the concept into a domaine privilégié (Subsection 3B).

A prohibited intervention must accordingly be one bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely. One of these is the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy.
This condition is often reconciled with the notion of state domaine réservé, which 'describes areas where States are free from international obligations and regulation'.

## B. The concept of domaine privilégié

Hence, I argue that non-intervention, too, should protect the fundamental interests of a state, rather than being limited to the domaine réservé. Yet, in contrast with necessity or the early doctrine of self-preservation, it does not provide justification for breaching the rights of other states, but results in a duty of abstention: states must refrain from meddling with the domaine privilégié of other states. This domaine privilégié includes not only the elements necessary for the very survival of a state but also those that are essential for its independence, autonomy and stability.
First, it protects the political organisation of the state, including the forms of government, the rule of law, personal, collective and political freedoms, as well as the electoral process in full (primary, local and general elections, referenda, etc). Under this new framework, the hack-and-leak operation that targeted the DNC would meddle with the American electoral process and, therefore, with the US domaine privilégié. It would also be affected in the event of cyber operations directed at the movie industry or press organs—like the SPE scenarios—as they seek to restrict the exercise of fundamental freedoms.
Secondly, it encompasses internal and external security. For instance, the 2015 data breach at the US Office of Personnel Management (OPM) compromised the security of the USA, as it could 'reveal the identities of CIA [Central Intelligence Agency] operatives serving under diplomatic cover'.69 In this case, the domaine privilégié of the USA was obviously affected.
Thirdly, it incorporates major economic interests, ie 'interests so essential that a breach of them threatens the economic ... stability' of the state.70 Key and energy industries, major employers, transports, banking transactions and telecommunications may qualify as such. For instance, and considering that the petrochemical sector 'is a core part of the Saudi economy',71 the cyberattacks against oil companies in Saudi Arabia may affect its domaine privilégié. # 4. A reconceptualisation of coercion
In this section, I will first explain the traditional definition of the concept of coercion, and why it is unsatisfactory in the digital era (Subsection 4A). I then put forward my own reappraisal of the concept of coercion (Subsection 4B).
## A. The traditional definition of coercion
Coercion must be equated with the implementation of ‘coercive measures’ or ‘coercive methods’ and must be distinguished from the mere influence or persuasion.⁷⁸ In fact, Vattel described interference as an ‘attempt to put a constraint on [the] deliberations’ of another state,⁷⁹ whereas Kant put down that ‘[n]o State shall by force interfere with the constitution or government of another State’.⁸⁰ The Montevideo Convention on the Rights and Duties of States of 1933 established a duty of non-recognition of situations ‘obtained by force whether this consist[ed] in the employment of arms, in threatening diplomatic representations, or in any other effective coercive measures’.⁸¹ The Charter of the Organization of American States (OAS) prevented states from ‘us[ing] or encouraging[ing] the use of coercive measures of an economic or political character in order to force the sovereign will of another state and obtain from it advantages of any kind’.⁸² It also underlined that ‘[n]o territorial acquisitions or special advantages obtained either by force or by other means of coercion shall be recognized’.⁸³ In the Nicaragua case, the ICJ used the term ‘methods of coercion’.⁸⁴ Another question that arises is whether intention is necessary. ## B. The reappraisal of coercion
As mentioned above, ‘coercion’ historically occurs ‘when a State deploys those means of pressure against another State, that are of a sufficiently serious nature to, and with the intention to, compel the latter to act in a certain way – or to refrain from acting in a certain way – and against its own will’. Yet, this definition is unsatisfactory in the cyber realm and fails to grasp new types of highly disruptive cyberattacks.¹⁰⁶ Any reappraisal of the coercion is a risky exercise, though, and we must beware of excessively watering down this concept, at the risk of hindering basic interstate relations.
In particular, the distinction between plain ‘influence’ and constraint must be maintained.¹⁰⁷ It is likely that states will use the information they obtained through cyberespionage operations to influence the negotiation strategies and decision-making of other states, in line with their own interests.¹⁰⁸ It is also likely that states that suffered cyberattacks or acts of cyberespionage will adapt their internal and external policies, either for the purpose of repairing the damage or for preventing further strikes. It is finally appropriate to touch on the issue of economic cyberespionage. Under the framework put forward in this article, it is clear that only the most severe forms of intellectual property theft (if there are any) would qualify as prohibited interventions—those prone to threatening the economic stability of a state. If this phenomenon is indeed problematic and calls—in my opinion—for legal answers, tailor-made rules are required. In that sense, the Paris Call is interesting, as signatories pledged to '[p]revent ICT-enabled theft of intellectual property, including trade secrets or other confidential business information, with the intent of providing competitive advantages to companies or commercial sector'.¹¹⁸
# 5. Conclusion
In this article, I championed the applicability of non-intervention in cyberspace. In my view, such applicability is welcomed by the international community and does not raise theoretical questions about the nature of sovereignty or the militarisation of cyberspace. However, I expressed fears that this principle becomes obsolete if we keep equating 'matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely'¹¹⁹ with the notion of domaine réservé. I thus recommended that, for the purpose of non-intervention, we ought to adopt the notion of state domaine privilégié. The latter encompasses the political organisation of a state, its internal and external security, major economic interests and public services (including the health and social systems), as well as the preservation of a state's environment. Then, I turned to the concept of coercion, arguing in favour of a 'balanced' reinterpretation of coercion—ie a

For permissions, please e-mail: journals.permissions@oup.com doi:10.1093/jcsl/kraa011 Advance Access Publication Date: 31 July 2020 # Reviving the Principle of Non-Intervention in Cyberspace: The Path Forward Thibault Moulin* ## Abstract The applicability of existing rules of international law (namely sovereignty or the prohibition to use force) is currently challenged in cyberspace. In contrast, the relevance of the non-intervention principle is accepted by states and raises less questions about the ‘territoriality’ or the ‘militarization’ of cyberspace. At first sight, it thus appears as a convenient source for the regulation of cyberthreats. However, the *Nicaragua* case also established a stringent test for a foreign interference to qualify as an unlawful intervention. First, it must bear ‘on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty to decide freely’ (ie the ‘domaine réservé’). Then, it must involve ‘methods of coercion in regard to such choices’. I contend that both criteria are maladjusted to address cyberthreats and must be reconceptualised. In fact, the *domaine réservé* describes domains where states are free from international rules. However, few domains, including electoral processes or main economic orientations, are totally isolated from international law. I thus argue that it must be reconceptualised into the so-called ‘domaine privilégié’. It consists of a domain with clear-cut contours, unaffected by the developments of international law, which encompasses the fundamental interests of a state and its population. Then, coercion describes situations where a state is compelled to act, or to refrain from acting, in a certain fashion. This traditional approach is also problematic, and I argue that coercion must be understood in terms of deprivation of control.
## 1. Introduction In his separate opinion attached to the *Nicaragua* case, ICJ President Nagendra Singh felt that he could not ‘conclude this opinion without emphasizing the key * Dr Thibault Moulin is a Teaching and Research Assistant at the Université Grenoble-Alpes, France. I am indebted to Professor Nicholas Tsagourias and the anonymous reviewers for their comments on an earlier draft. E-mail: thibault.moulin@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr Thibault Moulin importance of the doctrine of non-intervention in the affairs of States which is so vital for the peace and progress of the international community'. In fact, he considered that '[t]o ignore this doctrine is to undermine international order and to promote violence and bloodshed which may prove catastrophic in the end'. More than three decades later, international lawyers' attempts at regulating emerging technologies reveal that the 'principle' of non-intervention might be relevant in situations where there is no risk of 'bloodshed', in a world that lacks flesh and bones: cyberspace. In particular, there has been a renewed interest in this principle since the hack-and-leak operation that targeted the Democratic National Committee (DNC) in 2016 and the alleged interference of Russia in the US elections. If some commentators suggested that Moscow had 'cross[ed] a line', most experts nevertheless came to the conclusion that the so-called 'hack-and-leak' operations were not coercive, and did not constitute a prohibited intervention. The discomfort of the US government with describing this operation as a prohibited intervention was also clear.
As a matter of fact, Reviving the Principle of Non-Intervention in Cyberspace 425 the ICJ established a 2-fold test to determine the existence (or not) of a prohibited intervention. First, ‘[a] prohibited intervention must … be one bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely’.⁶ This concept is also known as the ‘domaine réservé’ (reserved domain) of the state. Secondly, a prohibited intervention must use ‘methods of coercion in regard to such choices, which must remain free ones’.⁷ It appears that under this stringent test, most cyber operations and attempts at influence will never qualify as prohibited interventions. According to most experts and as suggested above, the main reason is that ‘methods of coercion’ are lacking. I nevertheless argue that this is only part of the problem: in fact, both features are maladjusted to address the characteristics of cyberthreats. My main point, then, is that they must be reconceptualised, and that a new definition of non-intervention in the cyberspace context must be achieved. If we fail to do so, the principle of non-intervention will fall into disuse with regard to cyberthreats. I thus demonstrate that the old-fashioned concept of domaine réservé must be reconceptualised into what I call the ‘domaine privilégié’ Response to Russian Malicious Cyber Activity and Harassment’ (29 December 2016) <https: 12=""2016=""29=""document-president-actions-response-russian-malicious-cyber-activity=""the-press-office=""obamawhitehouse.archives.gov=""> accessed 3 October 2019. Yet, as underlined by Ryan Goodman, ‘[a]ll official statements by the Obama administration appear to include a studied avoidance of whether the Russian actions do or do not violate international law … It is safe to assume the specific word choice in the President’s statement is highly deliberate.’ See: R Goodman, ‘International Law and the US Response to Russian Election Interference’ (Just Security, 2017) <www.just security.org 35999=""international-law-response-russian-election-interference=""></www.just></https:> accessed 25 November 2019. The same thing could be said for Sweden, when the government declared in 2017 that ‘IT attacks could … improperly influence the outcome of democratic elections’. See: Prime Minister’s Office (Sweden), ‘National Security Strategy’ (2017) 18 <www.government.se 4aa5de=""contentassets=""0e04164d7eed462aa511ab03c890372e=""national-security-strategy.pdf=""> accessed 26 March 2020. He added: ‘no foreign power is allowed to influence Frenchmen’s choice; no foreign power is allowed to choose the next President of the Republic’. See: M Untersinger, ‘Cyberattaques: la France menace de “mesures de retorsion” tout Etat qui interférerait dans l’élection’ Le Monde (15 February 2017) <www.lemonde.fr 2017=""02=""15=""article=""cyberattaques-la-france-menace-de-mesures-de-retorsion-tout-etat-qui-interfererait-dans-l-election_5080323_4408996.html=""> accessed 21 December 2019.

I also argue in favour of a balanced reinterpretation of the concept of coercion, in order to encompass serious forms of foreign meddling, which deprive actors of control and render them powerless. In the end, the proposed definition is that a prohibited intervention occurs whenever a state (or a non-state actor located in that state) is deprived of control over matters within the domaine privilégié, due to the deliberate action of another state (as evidenced prima facie by the characteristics of the malware used).
Against this background, this article is structured as follows. In the next section, I explain that the principle of non-intervention is clearly applicable in cyberspace. I underline, in particular, that its application to cyberthreats is less controversial than other rules, namely sovereignty or the prohibition to use force—whose implementation in a 'digital' space instead of a 'physical' space remains disputed (Section 2). In the third section, I analyse what is domaine réservé and the reason why this concept is no longer adequate to address cyber activities. In particular, I raise doubts about the current integration of political processes and economic orientations within the domaine réservé, and I contend that it fails to protect those private actors that are vital to the social and cultural system of a state (such as press bodies). I then explain why the notion of domaine réservé should be replaced by the notion of domaine privilégié, what it means and how it would apply to cyberspace (Section 3). In the fourth section, I dwell on the concept of coercion and explain what it means. I underline that the traditional understanding of coercion fails to grasp situations where the state is deprived of its control, and I support a balanced reinterpretation of this concept (Section 4). Some conclusions are offered in the last section (Section 5).

# 3. A reconceptualisation of the domaine réservé In this section, I will first explain the concept of domaine réservé, and why this old-fashioned concept is unsatisfactory in the digital era (Subsection 3A). To alleviate this problem, I argue in favour of a reconceptualisation of the concept into a domaine privilégié (Subsection 3B).
# A. The concept of domaine réservé The exact wording used by the ICJ in the Nicaragua case to address the first component of a prohibited intervention was the following:... the principle forbids all States or groups of States to intervene directly or indirectly in internal or external affairs of other States. A prohibited intervention must accordingly be one bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely. One of these is the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy.[19] This condition is often reconciled with the notion of state domaine réservé, which 'describes areas where States are free from international obligations and regulation'.[20] The challenge with the domaine réservé resides in its shifting contours. In fact, the Permanent Court of International Justice (PCIJ) underlined that '[t]he question whether a certain matter is or is not solely within the jurisdiction of a State [ie if it is part of the domaine réservé] is an essentially relative question; it depends on the development of international relations'.[21] However, few domains are now totally Reviving the Principle of Non-Intervention in Cyberspace 431 isolated from international law.²² For instance, states are increasingly constrained in their ability to make free economic decisions.²³ Free-trade agreements—the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT),²⁴ General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS),²⁵ European Economic Area (EEA),²⁶ North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA),²⁷ ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA)²⁸ and Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA),²⁹ to name just a few—have prospered, and judicial mechanisms have even been created to enforce some of them.³⁰ Thus, in the current state of international law, most economic questions pulled out of the domaine réservé. But that's not all. States entered into international agreements in the area of electoral process too.³¹ From a certain perspective, one might conclude that it is not within the domaine réservé anymore. Let us imagine, for instance, that the Russians did not carry out a hack-and-leak operation against the DNC, but blackmailed the US President into resigning or directly tampered with the election results. Alternatively, let us imagine that ‘State A’ and ‘State B’ are both competing to sell jet-fighters to ‘State C’. State A decides to infect the electronic systems of the jet-fighters manufactured by State B, in order to cause failures, damage their reputation, end their production and —at the end of the day—win the bid and eliminate a competitor. If these areas are not within the domaine réservé anymore, then even those extreme forms of meddling in the political or economic affairs of another state would not qualify as prohibited interventions.
Another problem with the concept of domaine réservé is that it fails to regulate those cyber operations exclusively directed against private actors, even if they are vital to the social[33] and cultural system of a state.[34] For instance, the cyberattacks against Sony Pictures Entertainment (SPE) in 2014 revealed the attempts of foreign governments to meddle with values that are essential to liberal democracies, such as freedom of expression. As a matter of fact, 'the real motive of the operation appears to have been an attempt to prevent the film's global distribution as well as an attempt to deter SPE and other studios from insulting the North Korean regime'.[35] It must be said that this attempt was partially successful, as SPE had to cancel the film's release.[36] This decision was criticised by President Obama himself, who declared: [w]e cannot have a society where some dictator someplace can start imposing censorship here in the United States... Imagine if producers and distributors and others start engaging in self-censorship because they don't want to offend the sensibilities of someone who's sensibilities probably need to be offended.[37] Yet, and by virtue of the lex lata, the fact that such attacks were exclusively targeting a private company excludes the possibility to describe them in terms of prohibited interventions.[38] And indeed, the US government opted for an Reviving the Principle of Non-Intervention in Cyberspace 433 alternative term: ‘an act of cyber-vandalism’.³⁹ Let us imagine that the goal of North Korea was to prompt the adoption of a new law in the USA, which would increase movie censorship. Alternatively, let us imagine that the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK) launches a series of attacks against the movie industry in France, to protest the upcoming release of a similar comedy depicting the North Korean regime. They paralyse the movie industry, and studios experience significant economic losses. The goal is to put such pressure on the Minister of Culture that he is forced to refuse to grant the movie a ‘visa d’exploitation’ (ie the authorisation to broadcast a film).⁴⁰ If one admits that restrictions to the freedom of expression are still part of the domaine réservé—which is arguably not the case, as human rights conventions usually regulate this area⁴¹—these attacks are more likely to qualify as interventions because the private actor was only targeted to obtain something from the state. In fact, attacks against the movie industry or newspapers are on the rise, and the resort to ‘criminal hackers’ might just ‘provide a cheap and easy way of censoring the press’.⁴² To alleviate this risk, I suggest replacement of the old-fashioned concept of domaine réservé with the newer domaine privilégié.
## B. The concept of domaine privilégié The objections raised against the concept of domaine réservé are the following: it has been stripped of most of its content and it is maladjusted to the new contribution of non-state actors to the exercise of fundamental freedoms. Consequently, a domaine réservé—based principle of non-interventions fails to protect the free choice and the stability of a political, economic, social or cultural system from foreign attacks. Yet, in contrast with necessity or the early doctrine of self-preservation, it does not provide justification for breaching the rights of other states, but results in a duty of abstention: states must refrain from meddling with the domaine privilégié of other states. This domaine privilégié includes not only the elements necessary for the very survival of a state but also those that are essential for its independence, autonomy and stability.
First, it protects the political organisation of the state, including the forms of government, the rule of law, personal, collective and political freedoms, as well as the electoral process in full (primary, local and general elections, referenda, etc). Under this new framework, the hack-and-leak operation that targeted the DNC would meddle with the American electoral process and, therefore, with the US domaine privilégié. It would also be affected in the event of cyber operations directed at the movie industry or press organs—like the SPE scenarios—as they seek to restrict the exercise of fundamental freedoms.
Secondly, it encompasses internal and external security. For instance, the 2015 data breach at the US Office of Personnel Management (OPM) compromised the security of the USA, as it could 'reveal the identities of CIA [Central Intelligence Agency] operatives serving under diplomatic cover'.69 In this case, the domaine privilégié of the USA was obviously affected.
Thirdly, it incorporates major economic interests, ie 'interests so essential that a breach of them threatens the economic... stability' of the state.70 Key and energy industries, major employers, transports, banking transactions and telecommunications may qualify as such. For instance, and considering that the petrochemical sector 'is a core part of the Saudi economy',71 the cyberattacks against oil companies in Saudi Arabia may affect its domaine privilégié. The same would be true for the 2017 NotPetya attacks, which were aimed at disrupting Ukraine's financial system.72 Insofar as they may provoke the downfall Thibault Moulin of the aviation industry in 'State B', the cyberattacks induced by 'State A' in the fictitious example above would also impair the former's domaine privilégié.
Fourthly, it embraces public services, including health and social systems. Hence, state-sponsored attacks against hospitals would obviously affect the domaine privilégié. For instance, in March 2020, the Brno University Hospital had to turn away patients 'suffering serious conditions', and 'urgent surgeries' were postponed following a cyberattack, which shutdown all computers.73 In such situations, the impact on the domaine privilégié is obvious.
Fifthly, the domaine privilégié may extend to the preservation of a state's environment. A reconceptualisation of coercion In this section, I will first explain the traditional definition of the concept of coercion, and why it is unsatisfactory in the digital era (Subsection 4A). I then put forward my own reappraisal of the concept of coercion (Subsection 4B).
## A. The traditional definition of coercion Coercion must be equated with the implementation of ‘coercive measures’ or ‘coercive methods’ and must be distinguished from the mere influence or persuasion.⁷⁸ In fact, Vattel described interference as an ‘attempt to put a constraint on [the] deliberations’ of another state,⁷⁹ whereas Kant put down that ‘[n]o State shall by force interfere with the constitution or government of another State’.⁸⁰ The Montevideo Convention on the Rights and Duties of States of 1933 established a duty of non-recognition of situations ‘obtained by force whether this consist[ed] in the employment of arms, in threatening diplomatic representations, or in any other effective coercive measures’.⁸¹ The Charter of the Organization of American States (OAS) prevented states from ‘us[ing] or encouraging[ing] the use of coercive measures of an economic or political character in order to force the sovereign will of another state and obtain from it advantages of any kind’.⁸² It also underlined that ‘[n]o territorial acquisitions or special advantages obtained either by force or by other means of coercion shall be recognized’.⁸³ In the Nicaragua case, the ICJ used the term ‘methods of coercion’.⁸⁴ Another question that arises is whether intention is necessary. This may appear, from a certain perspective, as highly unsatisfactory, and it reveals that the concept of ‘coercion’ is in need of a reappraisal, to fit the new peculiarities of cyberattacks.¹⁰⁵ ## B. The reappraisal of coercion As mentioned above, ‘coercion’ historically occurs ‘when a State deploys those means of pressure against another State, that are of a sufficiently serious nature to, and with the intention to, compel the latter to act in a certain way – or to refrain from acting in a certain way – and against its own will’. Yet, this definition is unsatisfactory in the cyber realm and fails to grasp new types of highly disruptive cyberattacks.¹⁰⁶ Any reappraisal of the coercion is a risky exercise, though, and we must beware of excessively watering down this concept, at the risk of hindering basic interstate relations.
In particular, the distinction between plain ‘influence’ and constraint must be maintained.¹⁰⁷ It is likely that states will use the information they obtained through cyberespionage operations to influence the negotiation strategies and decision-making of other states, in line with their own interests.¹⁰⁸ It is also likely that states that suffered cyberattacks or acts of cyberespionage will adapt their internal and external policies, either for the purpose of repairing the damage or for preventing further strikes. metadata.abstract: The applicability of existing rules of international law (namely sovereignty or the prohibition to use force) is currently challenged in cyberspace. In contrast, the relevance of the non-intervention principle is accepted by states and raises less questions about the ‘territoriality’ or the ‘militarization’ of cyberspace. At first sight, it thus appears as a convenient source for the regulation of cyberthreats. However, the Nicaragua case also established a stringent test for a foreign interference to qualify as an unlawful intervention. First, it must bear ‘on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty to decide freely’ (ie the ‘domaine réservé’). Then, it must involve ‘methods of coercion in regard to such choices’. I contend that both criteria are maladjusted to address cyberthreats and must be reconceptualised. In fact, the domaine réservé describes domains where states are free from international rules. However, few domains, including electoral processes or main economic orientations, are totally isolated from international law. I thus argue that it must be reconceptualised into the so-called ‘domaine privilégié’. It consists of a domain with clear-cut contours, unaffected by the developments of international law, which encompasses the fundamental interests of a state and its population. Then, coercion describes situations where a state is compelled to act, or to refrain from acting, in a certain fashion. This traditional approach is also problematic, and I argue that coercion must be understood in terms of deprivation of control.
